tool.name: Vendor Compliance Questionnaire
tool.description:
Generate compliance questionnaires for organizations evaluating third-party 
products to integrate with the EUDIW ecosystem. Select your organisation's 
role, the product category you're evaluating, and the regulatory sources 
to include.

intermediaryTypes.label: RP Intermediary
intermediaryTypes.description:
An entity that acts on behalf of Relying Parties to interact with EUDI Wallets.
Per Article 5b(10), intermediaries are legally deemed Relying Parties and must not 
store transaction content.

scopeExtensions.label: Extended: DORA ICT Third-Party Provisions
scopeExtensions.description:
For RPs that are financial entities under DORA, intermediary vendors qualify 
as ICT third-party service providers with additional requirements.

categories.label: Registration
categories.description: Authorization to operate in the EUDIW ecosystem

eidas.label: eIDAS Framework
eidas.description: Core eIDAS Regulation and all binding Implementing Acts

related.label: Related Regulations
related.description: Additional legal requirements based on your context

architecture.label: Technical Specifications
architecture.description: EUDIW Technical Specifications for implementation guidance

items.name: Technical Specifications (TS1-TS14)
items.note: Filtered by selected Role and Product Category

views.label: Summary
views.description: High-level compliance domains with requirement counts

requirements.requirement: Intermediaries shall not store data about the content of transactions
requirements.explanation:
The no-storage mandate is the central privacy protection for wallet users 
when interacting through intermediaries. Vendors acting on behalf of RPs 
are deemed to be relying parties themselves and must not retain any data 
from wallet presentations beyond what is strictly necessary for immediate 
transaction completion.
requirements.legalText:
Intermediaries acting on behalf of relying parties shall be deemed to be 
relying parties and shall not store data about the content of the transaction.

requirements.requirement: Implement a Data Processing Agreement meeting GDPR Article 28 requirements
requirements.explanation:
When intermediaries process personal data on behalf of the RP, they act as 
data processors. A written contract (DPA) must exist specifying processing 
instructions, confidentiality, security measures, sub-processor conditions, 
data subject request assistance, and audit rights.
requirements.legalText:
Processing by a processor shall be governed by a contract or other legal act 
under Union or Member State law, that is binding on the processor with regard 
to the controller and that sets out the subject-matter and duration of the 
processing, the nature and purpose of the processing, the type of personal 
data and categories of data subjects and the obligations and rights of the 
controller.

requirements.requirement: Provide audit rights to the Relying Party
requirements.explanation:
The RP must be able to verify the vendor's compliance with processing 
instructions and security requirements. This includes rights to conduct 
audits and inspections, or to mandate that an independent auditor 
performs such verification.
requirements.legalText:
The processor shall make available to the controller all information 
necessary to demonstrate compliance with the obligations laid down in 
this Article and allow for and contribute to audits, including inspections, 
conducted by the controller or another auditor mandated by the controller.

requirements.requirement: Register as a Relying Party indicating intermediary status
requirements.explanation:
Any entity acting as an intermediary must register as a Relying Party with 
Member State authorities according to Topic 27 requirements, while explicitly 
indicating its intent to act as an intermediary. This registration establishes 
the legal basis for operation, enables oversight, and allows the intermediary 
to obtain an access certificate containing its own name and unique ID.
requirements.legalText:
Where a relying party intends to rely upon European Digital Identity 
Wallets for the provision of public or private services by means of 
digital interaction, the relying party shall register in the Member 
State where it is established.

requirements.requirement: Maintain a valid Relying Party Access Certificate
requirements.explanation:
Intermediaries must obtain and maintain access certificates from a 
notified Access Certificate Authority. This certificate authenticates 
the intermediary to wallet units and enables trust verification.

requirements.requirement: Implement appropriate technical and organizational security measures
requirements.explanation:
Vendors must implement security measures appropriate to the risk, 
including encryption, pseudonymization, confidentiality assurance, 
availability and resilience, and regular testing.
requirements.legalText:
Taking into account the state of the art, the costs of implementation 
and the nature, scope, context and purposes of processing as well as 
the risk of varying likelihood and severity for the rights and freedoms 
of natural persons, the controller and processor shall implement appropriate 
technical and organisational measures to ensure a level of security 
appropriate to the risk.

requirements.requirement: Notify the RP of data breaches without undue delay
requirements.explanation:
When a personal data breach occurs at the intermediary, they must 
notify the RP (as controller) without undue delay so the RP can 
fulfill its obligations to supervisory authorities and data subjects.
requirements.legalText:
The processor shall notify the controller without undue delay after 
becoming aware of a personal data breach.

requirements.requirement: Ensure personnel authorized to process data are bound by confidentiality
requirements.explanation:
All staff with access to wallet transaction data must be contractually 
or legally bound to maintain confidentiality.
requirements.legalText:
The processor shall ensure that persons authorised to process the 
personal data have committed themselves to confidentiality or are 
under an appropriate statutory obligation of confidentiality.

requirements.requirement: Process personal data only on documented instructions from the RP
requirements.explanation:
The vendor must not process wallet data for their own purposes. 
All processing must be based on the RP's documented instructions, 
including with regard to transfers of data to third countries.
requirements.legalText:
The processor shall process the personal data only on documented 
instructions from the controller, including with regard to transfers 
of personal data to a third country or an international organisation.

requirements.requirement: Support data subject rights requests
requirements.explanation:
The vendor must assist the RP in responding to data subject requests 
(access, rectification, erasure, restriction, portability, objection) 
to the extent the vendor has relevant data.
requirements.legalText:
The processor shall assist the controller by appropriate technical 
and organisational measures, insofar as this is possible, for the 
fulfilment of the controller's obligation to respond to requests for 
exercising the data subject's rights.

requirements.requirement: Display both intermediary and RP identity to wallet users
requirements.explanation:
When requesting data from wallets, the intermediary must ensure that 
wallet users can see both their own identity and the identity of the 
RP on whose behalf they are acting. This enables informed consent.
requirements.legalText:
Where relying parties intend to rely upon European Digital Identity 
Wallets, they shall identify themselves to the user.

requirements.requirement: Inform the RP of any legal requirement to process data beyond instructions
requirements.explanation:
If the vendor is legally required (e.g., by law enforcement) to process 
data beyond the RP's instructions, they must inform the RP before doing 
so (unless prohibited by law from disclosing).

requirements.requirement: Obtain RP authorization before engaging sub-processors
requirements.explanation:
The vendor must not engage another processor (sub-processor) without 
prior written authorization from the RP. This can be specific or general 
authorization with notification of changes.
requirements.legalText:
The processor shall not engage another processor without prior specific 
or general written authorisation of the controller. In the case of 
general written authorisation, the processor shall inform the controller 
of any intended changes concerning the addition or replacement of other 
processors.

requirements.requirement: Delete or return personal data at end of contract
requirements.explanation:
Upon termination of the service contract, the vendor must delete or 
return all personal data to the RP and certify deletion, unless EU or 
Member State law requires storage.
requirements.legalText:
At the choice of the controller, the processor shall delete or return 
all the personal data to the controller after the end of the provision 
of services relating to processing.

requirements.requirement: Register each intermediated RP at the appropriate Registrar
requirements.explanation:
The intermediary must register each RP it acts on behalf of at a 
Registrar in the Member State where that RP is established. If the 
Registrar issues registration certificates, the intermediary must 
obtain a certificate for each registered intended use.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet-relying parties shall at least provide the information set out 
in Annex I to national registers. Annex I(14-15) requires indication 
of intermediary status and association to intermediated RPs.

requirements.requirement: Provide legal evidence of RP relationship when registering
requirements.explanation:
When registering an intermediated RP, the intermediary must provide 
legally valid evidence (e.g., a contract) that the RP will use the 
intermediary's services. The Registrar must verify this evidence 
before registering the relationship.
requirements.legalText:
Registrars shall verify the accuracy, validity, authenticity and 
integrity of the information required, including the power of 
attorney of representatives of the wallet-relying parties.

requirements.requirement: Perform verification of attestations as agreed with RP
requirements.explanation:
The intermediary must verify the authenticity, revocation status, 
device binding, and user binding of PIDs and attestations received 
from wallet units, as well as wallet unit authenticity, according to 
what has been agreed with the Relying Party.
requirements.legalText:
Relying parties shall be responsible for carrying out the procedure 
for authenticating and validating person identification data and 
electronic attestation of attributes requested from European Digital 
Identity Wallets.

requirements.requirement: Implement TS12 for PSD2 Strong Customer Authentication when processing payment transactions
requirements.explanation:
Payment Service Providers (PSPs) using EUDI Wallet for Strong Customer 
Authentication must implement ARF Technical Specification 12 (Electronic 
Payments over SCA). TS12 defines how the wallet's cryptographic binding, 
dynamic linking, and attestation mechanisms satisfy PSD2 RTS requirements 
for authentication elements (knowledge, possession, inherence), independence 
of elements, and transaction linking.
requirements.legalText:
Payment service providers shall apply strong customer authentication where 
the payer initiates an electronic payment transaction. The authentication 
shall include elements which dynamically link the transaction to a specific 
amount and a specific payee.

requirements.requirement: Implement TS6 (OpenID4VCI) for attestation issuance into EUDI Wallets
requirements.explanation:
Attestation Issuers must implement the OpenID for Verifiable Credential 
Issuance (OpenID4VCI) protocol as specified in Technical Specification 6. 
This ensures interoperability with all compliant EUDI Wallet implementations 
across Member States. The protocol covers credential offer, authorization, 
token exchange, and credential endpoint interactions.
requirements.legalText:
European Digital Identity Wallets shall use the protocols and interfaces 
set out in this Regulation for the issuance of person identification data 
and electronic attestations of attributes.

requirements.requirement: Implement TS7 data deletion request interface for GDPR Article 17 compliance
requirements.explanation:
Relying Parties must implement the common data deletion request interface 
specified in Technical Specification 7. This enables wallet users to exercise 
their GDPR Article 17 right to erasure by requesting deletion of any data 
the RP has collected from wallet presentations. The interface provides a 
standardized machine-readable format for deletion requests.
requirements.legalText:
The data subject shall have the right to obtain from the controller the 
erasure of personal data concerning him or her without undue delay and 
the controller shall have the obligation to erase personal data without 
undue delay.

requirements.requirement: Register attestation schemas in the catalogue per TS11
requirements.explanation:
Attestation Issuers must register their attestation types in the catalogue 
of attributes and attestations as specified in Technical Specification 11. 
This enables discovery by Relying Parties and ensures attestations follow 
the common data model. The catalogue defines attribute schemas, rulebooks, 
and the relationship between attestation types.
requirements.legalText:
Qualified trust service providers issuing qualified electronic attestations 
of attributes shall ensure that the attestation schemas they use comply 
with the technical specifications set out in this Regulation.

requirements.requirement: Implement open standards per TS1 for EUDI Wallet interoperability
requirements.explanation:
All EUDIW ecosystem participants must implement the open standards mapped 
in Technical Specification 1. TS1 provides the authoritative mapping between 
regulatory requirements and specific open standards (e.g., OpenID4VCI, 
OpenID4VP, SD-JWT, mdoc/mDL). This ensures cross-border interoperability 
and prevents vendor lock-in.
requirements.legalText:
The protocols and interfaces for European Digital Identity Wallets shall 
be based on open standards to ensure interoperability across Member States.

requirements.requirement: Publish provider information per TS2 for discovery by wallets and RPs
requirements.explanation:
PID Providers, QEAA Providers, and Pub-EAA Providers must publish their 
provider information according to Technical Specification 2. This includes 
metadata endpoints, supported credential types, signing algorithms, and 
trust chain information. Publication enables wallet and RP discovery of 
available attestation providers.
requirements.legalText:
Providers of qualified electronic attestations of attributes shall notify 
their activities to the supervisory body and publish information about 
their services in a machine-readable format.

requirements.requirement: Verify Wallet Unit Attestation (WUA) per TS3 before issuing credentials
requirements.explanation:
Before issuing attestations, Issuers must verify the Wallet Unit Attestation 
as specified in Technical Specification 3. The WUA proves that the target 
wallet instance runs on a certified WSCD, has not been revoked, and possesses 
the cryptographic keys for device binding. This prevents issuance to 
compromised or non-compliant wallet instances.
requirements.legalText:
Before issuing person identification data or electronic attestations of 
attributes, providers shall verify the authenticity and validity of the 
wallet unit requesting the credential.

requirements.requirement: Implement TS8 remote signing protocol for QES/QESeal via EUDI Wallet
requirements.explanation:
Trust service providers offering remote qualified electronic signatures 
must implement the protocol specified in Technical Specification 8. This 
enables EUDI Wallet users to create legally binding QES using QTSP-managed 
signing keys while maintaining sole control through wallet-based authorization.
requirements.legalText:
An advanced electronic signature shall meet the requirements of being 
uniquely linked to and capable of identifying the signatory, created 
using electronic signature creation data that the signatory can use 
under their sole control.

requirements.requirement: Support pseudonym attestations per TS9 for privacy-preserving identification
requirements.explanation:
RPs and Issuers should support pseudonym attestations as specified in 
Technical Specification 9 when full identification is not required. This 
includes User Pseudonyms (UP) for persistent pseudonymous relationships 
and Wallet-RP Pseudonyms (WRP) for unlinkable transactions. Pseudonyms 
enable data minimization while maintaining accountability.
requirements.legalText:
European Digital Identity Wallets shall enable the user to selectively 
disclose to relying parties person identification data, electronic 
attestation of attributes, or specific data elements of such data or 
attestations, including by means of pseudonyms.

requirements.requirement: Provide data export capability per TS10 for GDPR portability compliance
requirements.explanation:
RPs and Issuers must provide data export capabilities as specified in 
Technical Specification 10. This supports GDPR Article 20 data portability 
rights, enabling users to obtain transaction logs, backup credentials, 
and migrate between wallet providers. Export formats must be machine-readable 
and commonly used.
requirements.legalText:
The data subject shall have the right to receive the personal data 
concerning him or her, which he or she has provided to a controller, 
in a structured, commonly used and machine-readable format and have 
the right to transmit those data to another controller.

requirements.requirement: Verify registration certificates presented by counterparties
requirements.explanation:
Relying Parties must verify registration certificates presented by PID 
Providers, Attestation Providers, or other RPs to confirm their legitimate 
registration status. This includes validating certificate signatures and 
checking against Trusted Lists.

requirements.requirement: Verify attestation authenticity and validity before acceptance
requirements.explanation:
Before accepting an attestation, the RP must verify its cryptographic 
signature, check it has not expired, and verify its revocation status. 
This includes verifying the issuer's access certificate chain.

requirements.requirement: Register intended uses and comply with access certificate policies
requirements.explanation:
Relying Parties must register their intended uses for requesting data 
and comply with the access certificate policies established by the 
Access Certificate Authority. Certificate revocation procedures must 
be followed.

requirements.requirement: Use valid RP Access Certificate for Wallet Unit authentication
requirements.explanation:
When initiating a presentation request, the Relying Party must present 
a valid RP Access Certificate that allows the Wallet Unit to verify 
the RP's registration and intended use.

requirements.requirement: Support pseudonym-based presentations where applicable
requirements.explanation:
Where Users choose to present pseudonymous attestations, the RP 
connector must correctly process pseudonym presentations and not 
attempt to correlate pseudonyms across transactions.

requirements.requirement: Publish RP trust anchor information for Wallet verification
requirements.explanation:
Relying Parties accessing EUDI Wallets must publish trust anchor 
information through the Access Certificate Authority notification 
process, enabling Wallet Units to verify RP legitimacy.

requirements.requirement: Process data deletion requests from Users
requirements.explanation:
When Users exercise their right to data deletion, RPs must process 
these requests according to GDPR requirements and ARF specifications. 
This includes responding to deletion requests within mandated timeframes.

requirements.requirement: Handle pseudonym verification requests correctly
requirements.explanation:
When a User presents using a pseudonym, the Relying Party must correctly 
process the pseudonymous presentation without attempting unlawful 
de-anonymization or cross-correlation.

requirements.requirement: Respond to User deletion requests within timeframes
requirements.explanation:
When processing data deletion requests, the RP must respond within 
the timeframes specified in GDPR Article 17, providing confirmation 
of deletion or valid grounds for refusal.

requirements.requirement: Support W3C Digital Credentials API for presentation requests
requirements.explanation:
If the Relying Party supports the W3C Digital Credentials API, presentation 
requests must conform to the API specification and properly handle the 
browser-mediated credential exchange flow.

requirements.requirement: Handle revocation status unavailability gracefully
requirements.explanation:
When revocation status information is unavailable, the Relying Party 
Instance should not repeatedly request status lists and must implement 
appropriate fallback behavior as specified.

requirements.requirement: Support proximity identification flows
requirements.explanation:
Relying Party Instances that support proximity identification must 
implement the specified BLE or NFC protocols for local credential 
presentation without internet connectivity.

requirements.requirement: Handle registration certificate updates and renewals
requirements.explanation:
Relying Parties must properly handle registration certificate lifecycle 
events including updates, renewals, and revocations, updating their 
stored certificates accordingly.

requirements.requirement: Include mandatory contractual provisions per DORA Article 30
requirements.explanation:
When the RP is a DORA-regulated financial entity, the contract with the 
ICT third-party (intermediary) must include all provisions specified in 
DORA Article 30(2), covering service descriptions, locations, security 
requirements, data protection, and termination rights.
requirements.legalText:
Contractual arrangements on the use of ICT services shall include at 
least the following: (a) a clear and complete description of all 
functions and ICT services to be provided; (b) the locations where 
functions and ICT services are to be provided and data processed; 
(c) provisions on availability, authenticity, integrity and 
confidentiality in relation to data protection...
requirements.notes:
DORA ICT requirements apply IN ADDITION to eIDAS intermediary requirements.
When the RP is a DORA-regulated financial entity, both sets apply.

requirements.requirement: Provide audit rights as required by DORA Article 30(2)(e)
requirements.explanation:
The contract must grant the financial entity (and its supervisory 
authority) full rights of access, inspection, and audit of the ICT 
third-party service provider.
requirements.legalText:
DORA: The rights of the financial entity and, where applicable, the relevant 
competent authority in relation to access, inspection and audit of the 
ICT third-party service provider.
GDPR: The processor shall make available to the controller all information 
necessary to demonstrate compliance and allow for and contribute to audits.

requirements.requirement: Support exit strategies and transition planning
requirements.explanation:
The vendor must support the financial entity's exit strategy with 
mandatory transition periods, data migration, and continuity of service 
during transitions to alternative providers.
requirements.legalText:
Provisions on exit strategies, including a mandatory adequate transition 
period during which the ICT third-party service provider will continue 
providing the respective functions or ICT services.

requirements.requirement: Participate in the financial entity's ICT risk management framework
requirements.explanation:
The intermediary must cooperate with the financial entity's overall ICT 
risk management program, including risk assessments, control testing, 
and remediation activities.

requirements.requirement: Provide information required for the financial entity's Register of ICT TPPs
requirements.explanation:
Financial entities must maintain a register of all ICT third-party 
providers. The intermediary must provide all required information 
including entity details, services provided, criticality assessments, 
and contractual terms.

requirements.requirement: Support due diligence assessment before contract signing
requirements.explanation:
Before entering into a contractual arrangement, the financial entity 
must conduct due diligence on the ICT TPP. The vendor must provide 
information on their financial stability, ICT risk management 
capabilities, and compliance posture.

requirements.requirement: Notify the financial entity of ICT-related incidents
requirements.explanation:
The intermediary must notify the financial entity without undue delay 
of any ICT-related incidents that may impact the service, enabling 
the financial entity to fulfill its own incident reporting obligations.
requirements.legalText:
DORA: The obligation of the ICT third-party service provider to provide 
assistance in case of an ICT incident at no additional cost.
GDPR: The processor shall notify the controller without undue delay after 
becoming aware of a personal data breach.

requirements.requirement: Participate in threat-led penetration testing if required
requirements.explanation:
If the financial entity is required to conduct threat-led penetration 
testing (TLPT), the ICT TPP must cooperate with such testing when 
relevant to the services provided.

requirements.requirement: Maintain business continuity arrangements for ICT services
requirements.explanation:
The intermediary must maintain adequate business continuity and disaster 
recovery arrangements to ensure service availability meets the financial 
entity's requirements.
requirements.legalText:
Provisions on the implementation and testing of business continuity 
measures and on the establishment of contingency plans.

requirements.requirement: Obtain approval for subcontracting of critical functions
requirements.explanation:
If the intermediary subcontracts any part of the ICT service that 
supports critical or important functions, prior approval from the 
financial entity is required. The subcontractor must meet equivalent 
requirements.
requirements.legalText:
DORA: Provisions on the possibility, conditions and modalities of subcontracting 
by the ICT third-party service provider, and in particular for 
subcontracting ICT services supporting critical or important functions.
GDPR: The processor shall not engage another processor without prior specific 
or general written authorisation of the controller.

requirements.requirement: Provide information for concentration risk assessment
requirements.explanation:
The intermediary must provide information enabling the financial entity 
to assess ICT concentration risk, including data on other financial 
entities served and interdependencies with other ICT providers.

requirements.requirement: Comply with enhanced oversight if designated as Critical ICT TPP
requirements.explanation:
If the ESAs designate the intermediary as a Critical ICT Third-Party 
Provider (CTPP), they become subject to enhanced oversight including 
direct supervision by the Lead Overseer, regular assessments, and 
additional reporting requirements.
requirements.notes:
This requirement is conditional - it only applies if the ESAs designate 
the vendor as Critical based on systemic importance criteria (Art. 31(2)).
Most intermediaries will NOT be designated as Critical ICT TPPs.

requirements.requirement: Display both intermediary and RP identity before requesting attestations
requirements.explanation:
When the intermediary requests attestations from a wallet user, the wallet 
must display both the intermediary's identity (as the direct requester) and 
the identity of the ultimate Relying Party on whose behalf the intermediary 
is acting. This ensures informed consent.
requirements.legalText:
When an intermediary requests attestations from a wallet unit, the wallet 
unit shall display both the identity of the intermediary and the identity 
of the relying party on whose behalf the intermediary is acting.

requirements.requirement: Ensure RP's intended data requests are accurately communicated to wallet
requirements.explanation:
The intermediary must not modify, expand, or alter the RP's registered data 
request when forwarding to wallets. Only the attributes registered by the RP 
may be requested.
requirements.legalText:
Relying parties shall not request users to provide any data other than 
that indicated pursuant to paragraph 2, point (c).

requirements.requirement: Forward presentation requests without modification of requested attributes
requirements.explanation:
The intermediary must accurately relay the RP's attribute request to the 
wallet without adding, removing, or modifying the requested attributes. The 
request must match what the RP registered with supervisory authorities.

requirements.requirement: Forward wallet presentations to RP without modification
requirements.explanation:
The intermediary must relay the wallet's presentation to the RP exactly as 
received, without altering, extracting, or processing the credential data. 
The presentation integrity must be preserved.
requirements.legalText:
Intermediaries acting on behalf of relying parties shall be deemed to be 
relying parties and shall not store data about the content of the transaction.

requirements.requirement: Support both remote and proximity presentation protocols
requirements.explanation:
If the RP requires both remote and proximity (offline) presentation 
scenarios, the intermediary must support the relevant ISO/IEC 18013-5 and 
ISO/IEC TS 18013-7 protocols.

requirements.requirement: Forward attributes only to the requesting RP after verification
requirements.explanation:
After receiving attestation data from a wallet and verifying it, the 
intermediary must forward the attributes ONLY to the specific RP on whose 
behalf the request was made. If verification fails, no attributes may be 
forwarded.

requirements.requirement: Maintain up-to-date Trusted Lists for PID Providers
requirements.explanation:
The intermediary must maintain current copies of the Trusted Lists containing 
PID Provider trust anchors (public keys/certificates). These lists are 
published by Member States and the Commission and must be refreshed 
regularly to capture additions, modifications, and revocations.
requirements.legalText:
Each Member State shall establish, maintain and publish trusted lists, 
including information related to the qualified trust service providers 
for which it is responsible.

requirements.requirement: Maintain up-to-date Trusted Lists for Attestation Providers
requirements.explanation:
The intermediary must maintain current copies of Trusted Lists for qualified 
and non-qualified electronic attestation of attributes (QEAA/EAA) providers. 
These trust anchors are essential for validating attestation signatures.

requirements.requirement: Obtain trust anchors only from official Trusted List sources
requirements.explanation:
Trust anchors for verification must be obtained exclusively from official 
EU and Member State Trusted Lists, not from third-party aggregators or 
unofficial sources. This ensures the authenticity of verification keys.

requirements.requirement: Validate attestation signatures using official trust anchors
requirements.explanation:
The intermediary must verify the cryptographic signatures on attestations 
and PIDs using the public keys from official Trusted Lists. Invalid or 
untrusted signatures must result in rejection.
requirements.legalText:
The validity of attestations shall be verified using the trust anchors 
published in official Trusted Lists.

requirements.requirement: Verify attestation revocation status before acceptance
requirements.explanation:
Before accepting a presentation as valid, the intermediary must check the 
revocation status of the attestation. This may involve checking validity 
status lists, OCSP responses, or other revocation mechanisms as specified 
by the issuer.

requirements.requirement: Verify the wallet unit's device binding
requirements.explanation:
The intermediary must verify that the presentation is bound to the wallet 
unit's secure cryptographic device (WSCD), confirming that the presenter 
controls the private key associated with the attestations.

requirements.requirement: Verify presentation freshness (anti-replay)
requirements.explanation:
The intermediary must verify that presentations are fresh and not replayed 
by checking nonces, timestamps, or session binding. Stale or replayed 
presentations must be rejected.

requirements.requirement: Ensure secure channel for transmission to RP
requirements.explanation:
The intermediary must establish and maintain a secure, encrypted channel 
when forwarding wallet presentations to the RP. Transport layer security 
(TLS 1.3 or equivalent) is required.

requirements.requirement: Implement measures to prevent replay attacks
requirements.explanation:
The intermediary must implement mechanisms to detect and prevent replay of 
previously received wallet presentations. Nonce-based challenge-response 
and session binding are typical approaches.

requirements.requirement: Implement secure key management for verification operations
requirements.explanation:
The intermediary must implement secure storage and handling of any 
cryptographic material used in verification operations. Keys must be 
protected against unauthorized access, modification, and extraction.

requirements.requirement: Protect verification results integrity
requirements.explanation:
The verification result communicated to the RP must be protected against 
tampering. The RP must be able to trust that the intermediary's verification 
outcome is authentic and unmodified.

requirements.requirement: Maintain audit logs of verification operations
requirements.explanation:
The intermediary should maintain logs of verification operations including 
verification timestamps, outcomes, and any errors. These logs support 
dispute resolution and compliance auditing while respecting privacy 
(no attestation content should be logged).
requirements.legalText:
The controller and processor shall implement measures to ensure a process 
for regularly testing, assessing and evaluating the effectiveness of 
technical and organisational measures for ensuring the security of processing.
requirements.notes:
Logs must not contain attestation content (due to no-storage mandate) 
but may contain verification metadata (pass/fail, timestamp, error codes).

requirements.requirement: Do not extract or log individual attribute values from presentations
requirements.explanation:
Beyond the no-storage mandate, intermediaries must not extract, log, or 
analyze individual attribute values from wallet presentations. The 
presentation should be treated as an opaque payload for forwarding.

requirements.requirement: Do not correlate or link user presentations across different RPs
requirements.explanation:
Intermediaries serving multiple RPs must not correlate wallet user activity 
across different RP interactions. Each RP relationship must be treated 
independently to preserve user unlinkability.

requirements.requirement: Delete attestation data immediately after forwarding to RP
requirements.explanation:
The intermediary must completely delete all PIDs, attestations, and user 
attributes immediately after sending them to the intermediated RP. If 
forwarding fails or is not performed (e.g., due to verification failure), 
deletion must still occur immediately after completing all necessary 
verifications.

requirements.requirement: Specify RP details in each presentation request to wallet
requirements.explanation:
When requesting attestations from a wallet, the intermediary must include 
complete information about the intermediated RP: user-friendly name, unique 
identifier, Registrar URL, intended use identifier, and description. This 
enables the wallet to display accurate RP information to the user.
requirements.legalText:
For each intended use, a list of the data, including attestations and 
attributes, that the relying party intends to request, a user-friendly 
name and a technical name, the attestation type and a description of 
intended use of the data.

requirements.requirement: Support mandatory credential formats (ISO 18013-5 and W3C VC)
requirements.explanation:
The intermediary must be capable of verifying attestations in both mandated 
formats: ISO/IEC 18013-5:2021 (mDoc) and W3C Verifiable Credentials Data 
Model 1.1. This ensures interoperability across the EUDIW ecosystem.
requirements.annexReference:
Annex II of 2024/2979:
- ISO/IEC.18013-5:2021
- 'Verifiable Credentials Data Model 1.1', W3C Recommendation

requirements.requirement: Support selective disclosure in both credential formats
requirements.explanation:
The intermediary's verification implementation must correctly handle 
selectively disclosed attributes in both mDoc and VC formats. Verification 
must succeed even when only a subset of attributes is presented.

requirements.requirement: Consider certification for cryptographic components
requirements.explanation:
Depending on the assurance level required by the RP, the intermediary may 
need to demonstrate that its cryptographic implementations meet recognized 
standards (e.g., FIPS 140-2/3, Common Criteria). This is especially relevant 
for high-assurance use cases.
requirements.notes:
This is a conditional requirement based on the RP's risk assessment and 
the sensitivity of the use case. Not all intermediaries will require 
certification.

requirements.requirement: Comply with embedded disclosure policies in attestations
requirements.explanation:
Electronic attestations of attributes may contain embedded disclosure 
policies that specify conditions the relying party must meet to access 
the attestation. The intermediary must verify RP compliance with these 
policies and ensure the wallet can inform the user of the result.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet instances shall verify whether the wallet-relying party complies 
with the requirements of the embedded disclosure policy and inform the 
wallet user of the result.

requirements.requirement: Support WebAuthn specification for pseudonym generation
requirements.explanation:
When the intermediary supports pseudonymous authentication from wallet 
units, it must support the WebAuthn specification as mandated in 
Annex V of the Integrity regulation. This enables privacy-preserving 
authentication without revealing user identity.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet units shall support the generation of pseudonyms for wallet users 
in compliance with the technical specifications set out in Annex V.
requirements.annexReference:
Annex V of 2024/2979:
- 'Web Authentication', W3C Recommendation

requirements.requirement: Support relying-party-specific pseudonyms
requirements.explanation:
Wallet units generate unique pseudonyms per relying party, ensuring 
unlinkability across different RPs. The intermediary must correctly 
handle these RP-specific pseudonyms in verification flows.
requirements.legalText:
A pseudonym shall be relying-party specific, meaning that only wallets 
and relying parties can link different transactions to the same pseudonym.

requirements.requirement: Use valid Wallet-Relying Party Access Certificate
requirements.explanation:
The intermediary must use a valid Wallet-Relying Party Access Certificate 
(issued by its Registrar) when interacting with wallet units. The 
certificate identifies the intermediary and enables the wallet to verify 
its registration status.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet providers shall ensure that wallet solutions support protocols 
and interfaces which allow wallet-relying parties to present a valid 
wallet-relying party access certificate.

requirements.requirement: Support data erasure request protocol
requirements.explanation:
The intermediary must support the protocol for data erasure requests 
from wallet users. When a user requests erasure of their data from 
an RP (via the wallet), the intermediary must correctly relay or 
support this request.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet providers shall ensure that wallet solutions support protocols 
and interfaces which allow users to request erasure of their personal 
data from wallet-relying parties.

requirements.requirement: Support user reporting to data protection authorities
requirements.explanation:
Wallet units allow users to report RPs to data protection authorities 
if they suspect unlawful data requests. The intermediary's identity 
(as the entity making the request on behalf of the RP) will be visible 
to users and may be included in such reports.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet providers shall ensure that wallet units allow wallet users to 
easily report wallet-relying parties to supervisory authorities 
established under Article 51 of Regulation (EU) 2016/679.

requirements.requirement: Include intermediary access certificate and RP registration certificate in requests
requirements.explanation:
When requesting attestations from a wallet on behalf of an intermediated RP, the 
intermediary must include both: (1) its own access certificate (proving its identity 
as a registered intermediary), and (2) the registration certificate of the 
intermediated RP, if the RP has one. This enables the wallet to verify both 
the intermediary and the ultimate service provider.
requirements.legalText:
When requested by an intermediated Relying Party, an intermediary SHALL request 
a presentation of attributes from a specific Wallet Unit. In the request, the 
intermediary SHALL include the intermediary's access certificate and the 
registration certificate of the Relying Party, if available.
requirements.notes:
This is the technical implementation of RPI_06. The access certificate comes from 
the intermediary's own registration. The RP registration certificate is obtained 
during the intermediary's registration of each intermediated RP (per RPI_03).

requirements.requirement: Ensure intermediary-RP contractual relationship is registered
requirements.explanation:
Before the intermediary can act on behalf of an RP, the contractual relationship 
between them must be registered with the relevant Registrar. The wallet verifies 
this registration when processing requests (per RPI_07a). If the relationship 
is not registered, the wallet will warn the user that the intermediary's 
authority to act for the RP cannot be verified.
requirements.legalText:
When registering an intermediated Relying Party, an intermediary SHALL provide 
legally valid evidence that this Relying Party will indeed use the services of 
this intermediary to interact with Wallet Units. The Registrar SHALL verify 
this evidence and register the relationship between the intermediary and the 
intermediated Relying Party.
requirements.notes:
This corresponds to ARF RPI_04 and supports wallet verification per RPI_07a. 
The intermediary must ensure this registration is complete BEFORE accepting 
intermediation requests from an RP, otherwise wallet users will see verification 
failures.

requirements.requirement: Support attestation status list verification mechanisms
requirements.explanation:
The intermediary must support attestation status verification using the mechanisms 
specified in ARF Topic 7 (Attestation Revocation). This includes checking 
Attestation Status Lists or Attestation Revocation Lists published by PID/EAA 
providers to verify that attestations have not been revoked.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet providers shall ensure that wallet units support mechanisms for 
checking the revocation status of attestations in accordance with the 
methods specified by the issuing PID Provider or Attestation Provider.
requirements.notes:
This covers ARF Topic 7 (VCR_*) and Topic 14 (VAL_*) verification requirements. 
Attestation Status Lists (VCR_11) are the primary mechanism for efficient 
batch revocation checking without per-credential queries.

requirements.requirement: Register as an Attestation Provider with the competent authority
requirements.explanation:
Any entity issuing electronic attestations of attributes must register 
with a Member State authority. Registration establishes eligibility to 
issue attestations and enables inclusion in Trusted Lists.
requirements.legalText:
Electronic attestation of attributes issued by or on behalf of a public 
sector body responsible for an authentic source shall be issued in 
accordance with the requirements laid down in this Regulation.

requirements.requirement: Publish Provider Information according to the standard schema
requirements.explanation:
Attestation Providers must publish machine-readable information about 
their services, including supported attestation types, data sources, 
and issuance policies. This enables wallets and relying parties to 
discover and evaluate providers.
requirements.legalText:
Providers issuing attestations to European Digital Identity Wallet units 
shall publish information in accordance with the data model set out in 
Annex I.

requirements.requirement: Update Provider Information within 24 hours of changes
requirements.explanation:
When any information in the published Provider Information changes 
(e.g., new attestation types, policy updates), the provider must 
update the published data within 24 hours.

requirements.requirement: Obtain inclusion in national or EU Trusted Lists if issuing qualified attestations
requirements.explanation:
Providers of Qualified Electronic Attestations of Attributes (QEAAs) 
must be included in the national Trusted List as a QTSP. This enables 
relying parties to verify the qualified status of the attestations.
requirements.notes:
This requirement only applies to QEAA issuance. Non-qualified EAAs 
may be issued without QTSP status but must still register.

requirements.requirement: Issue attestations in mandated credential formats (mDoc and/or W3C VC)
requirements.explanation:
Attestations must be issued in one or both of the mandated formats: 
ISO/IEC 18013-5 (mDoc/mdoc) and/or W3C Verifiable Credentials Data Model 1.1. 
The format(s) supported must be published in Provider Information.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet units shall support the encoding of attestations in accordance 
with the technical specifications set out in Annex II.
hlr: "Iss_02"

requirements.requirement: Bind attestations to the Wallet Unit's cryptographic device
requirements.explanation:
Attestations must be cryptographically bound to the Wallet Unit's 
secure cryptographic device (WSCD), ensuring that the attestation 
can only be presented from the authorised wallet instance.
requirements.legalText:
Wallet providers shall ensure that wallet units bind attestations to 
the wallet secure cryptographic device.
hlr: "Iss_06"

requirements.requirement: Implement the OpenID4VCI issuance protocol (TS6)
requirements.explanation:
The issuance platform must support the OpenID for Verifiable Credential 
Issuance (OpenID4VCI) protocol as specified in TS6, enabling standardised 
credential issuance to EUDI Wallets across Member States.
hlr: "Iss_01"

requirements.requirement: Support batch issuance for multiple attestations
requirements.explanation:
The platform should support efficient batch issuance when a user 
requests multiple attestations simultaneously, avoiding redundant 
authentication steps.
hlr: "Iss_03"

requirements.requirement: Verify user identity before issuing attestations
requirements.explanation:
Before issuing an attestation, the provider must verify the user's 
identity to a level of assurance appropriate for the attestation type. 
For qualified attestations, this requires high assurance identity proofing.
requirements.legalText:
Providers of electronic attestation of attributes shall verify the 
identity of the natural or legal person to whom the electronic 
attestation of attributes is issued.

requirements.requirement: Obtain data from authentic sources with verified provenance
requirements.explanation:
Attestation data must be obtained from authentic sources (authoritative 
databases, registries) with verified data provenance. The platform must 
maintain audit trails of data source queries.
requirements.legalText:
Providers of electronic attestation of attributes shall obtain the 
data for the attributes from authentic sources.

requirements.requirement: Include attestation validity period and issuance timestamp
requirements.explanation:
Each attestation must include a clearly defined validity period 
(valid_from and valid_until) and issuance timestamp. Expired 
attestations must be rejected by wallets.
hlr: "Iss_07"

requirements.requirement: Support attestation renewal and re-issuance workflows
requirements.explanation:
The platform must support workflows for renewing attestations before 
expiry and re-issuing attestations when the underlying data changes. 
Users should be notified of upcoming expiry.
hlr: "Iss_05"

requirements.requirement: Publish attestation status lists for revocation checking
requirements.explanation:
The issuer must maintain and publish attestation status lists 
(revocation/validity lists) that enable relying parties to verify 
that attestations have not been revoked since issuance.
requirements.legalText:
PID Providers and Attestation Providers shall publish validity status 
information of revoked or suspended attestations.
hlr: "VCR_01"

requirements.requirement: Update revocation status within defined time limits
requirements.explanation:
When an attestation is revoked, the status list must be updated within 
the defined maximum propagation time (typically 24 hours for standard 
attestations, immediate for critical security revocations).

requirements.requirement: Notify wallet users when their attestations are revoked
requirements.explanation:
When an attestation is revoked, the issuer should notify the affected 
wallet user through available channels, enabling them to take 
appropriate action (e.g., request re-issuance).
hlr: "VCR_04"

requirements.requirement: Support suspension and reinstatement of attestations
requirements.explanation:
Beyond permanent revocation, the platform should support temporary 
suspension of attestations (e.g., during fraud investigation) with 
the ability to reinstate if the issue is resolved.
hlr: "VCR_02"

requirements.requirement: Protect attestation signing keys in secure cryptographic devices
requirements.explanation:
The private keys used to sign attestations must be stored and used 
within secure cryptographic devices (HSMs or equivalent) that prevent 
extraction and ensure key integrity.
requirements.legalText:
Qualified trust service providers shall use trustworthy systems and 
products that are protected against modification and ensure the 
technical security and reliability of the processes supported by them.

requirements.requirement: Use signing algorithms from the approved list
requirements.explanation:
Attestation signatures must use cryptographic algorithms from the 
approved list in Annex of the Integrity Regulation (e.g., ECDSA P-256, 
EdDSA Ed25519, RSA-PSS).

requirements.requirement: Implement key rotation procedures
requirements.explanation:
The platform must support cryptographic key rotation with documented 
procedures for transitioning to new signing keys while maintaining 
validity of previously issued attestations.

requirements.requirement: Publish attestation types to the Common Catalogue (TS11)
requirements.explanation:
Attestation types issued by the provider should be registered in the 
Common Catalogue of Attestation Types, enabling discoverability by 
wallets, relying parties, and users.

requirements.requirement: Document attestation schema including mandatory and optional attributes
requirements.explanation:
Each attestation type must have a published schema defining the 
mandatory and optional attributes, data types, and semantic meaning 
of each field.

requirements.requirement: Apply data minimisation principles to attestation content
requirements.explanation:
Attestations should contain only the attributes necessary for their 
intended purpose. Issuers should offer selective disclosure-friendly 
attestation designs where possible.
requirements.legalText:
The controller shall implement appropriate technical and organisational 
measures for ensuring that, by default, only personal data which are 
necessary for each specific purpose of the processing are processed.

requirements.requirement: Do not embed tracking identifiers in attestations
requirements.explanation:
Attestations must not contain hidden or overt tracking identifiers 
that could enable correlation of user presentations across different 
relying parties.

requirements.requirement: Enable cross-border recognition of attestations
requirements.explanation:
Attestations issued in one Member State must be verifiable and 
recognisable in all other Member States. The platform must ensure 
interoperability through adherence to common standards.
requirements.legalText:
An electronic attestation of attributes issued in one Member State 
shall be recognised as an electronic attestation of attributes in 
all other Member States.

requirements.requirement: Support both SD-JWT and mDoc credential formats
requirements.explanation:
For maximum interoperability, the platform should support issuing 
attestations in both SD-JWT-VC and ISO mDoc formats, allowing 
relying parties to request their preferred format.

requirements.requirement: Comply with PID Rulebook format and attribute requirements
requirements.explanation:
When issuing Person Identification Data (PIDs), the issuance platform must 
comply with the PID Rulebook specifications including namespace conventions, 
attribute encoding (CBOR for mDoc), portrait image quality requirements, 
and domestic namespace publication.
requirements.notes:
Covers PID-specific format requirements. Non-PID attestation providers 
should refer to the relevant Attestation Rulebook instead.

requirements.requirement: Support all mandatory attestation formats for the attestation type
requirements.explanation:
The issuance platform must offer attestations in all formats required by 
the applicable Rulebook. For most attestation types, this means supporting 
both ISO 18013-5 (mDoc) and SD-JWT-VC formats with correct encoding.

requirements.requirement: Implement revocation according to applicable Rulebook specifications
requirements.explanation:
The platform must implement attestation revocation as specified in the 
applicable Rulebook. This includes publishing revocation status, supporting 
suspension where required, and ensuring revocation information is available 
within defined propagation times.

requirements.requirement: Maintain accurate registration information and update on changes
requirements.explanation:
Attestation providers must maintain accurate information in Member State 
registries and update this information promptly when changes occur. This 
includes contact details, supported attestation types, and operational status.

requirements.requirement: Publish PID/Attestation Provider trust anchor information
requirements.explanation:
PID and Attestation Providers must publish trust anchor information that 
enables Wallet Units and Relying Parties to verify issued attestations. 
This includes signing certificate publication and Trusted List inclusion.

requirements.requirement: Verify Wallet Unit Attestation during issuance
requirements.explanation:
Before issuing a PID or device-bound attestation, the provider must verify 
the Wallet Unit Attestation (WUA) to ensure the target Wallet Unit is 
genuine and certified. This includes validating WUA signature and 
checking revocation status.

requirements.requirement: Include embedded disclosure policies in attestations
requirements.explanation:
Where applicable, attestation providers must include embedded disclosure 
policies in issued attestations. These policies guide Wallet Units on 
appropriate disclosure behavior for the attestation.

requirements.requirement: Use registration certificates for Provider authentication
requirements.explanation:
If a registration certificate was issued during registration, the 
provider must use it for authentication in interactions with Wallet Units 
as specified in the technical specifications.

requirements.requirement: Comply with SD-JWT VC format requirements for PID issuance
requirements.explanation:
When issuing PIDs in SD-JWT VC format, providers must include required 
claims (vct), encode attributes per specification, ensure proper date 
formatting, and make all claims selectively disclosable.

requirements.requirement: Comply with mDoc format requirements for PID issuance
requirements.explanation:
When issuing PIDs in ISO 18013-5 mDoc format, providers must use correct 
document types, element identifiers, value encodings, and ensure each 
PID contains at most one attribute with the same identifier.

requirements.requirement: Support both attestation status mechanisms
requirements.explanation:
PID and Attestation Providers must support both the Attestation Status 
List mechanism and Token Status List mechanism for revocation checking 
as specified in the technical specifications.

requirements.requirement: Implement complete OpenID4VCI protocol requirements
requirements.explanation:
Attestation Providers must implement all required elements of the 
OpenID4VCI protocol, including credential offer structures, authorization 
flows, and credential response handling.

requirements.requirement: Publish trust anchor information in common format
requirements.explanation:
PID Providers must publish trust anchor information according to the 
common set of information specified by the Commission, enabling 
Wallet Units and Relying Parties to verify attestation authenticity.

requirements.requirement: Obtain and maintain qualified trust service provider (QTSP) status
requirements.explanation:
To provide qualified trust services, the vendor must obtain QTSP status 
from a conformity assessment body in a Member State and be listed on 
the national Trusted List.
requirements.legalText:
A trust service provider may start its activity as a qualified trust 
service provider only after the qualified status, and where applicable, 
the qualified status of the trust services it provides, has been 
verified.

requirements.requirement: Undergo regular conformity assessment (at least every 24 months)
requirements.explanation:
QTSPs must undergo conformity assessment at least every 24 months 
by an accredited conformity assessment body to verify continued 
compliance with eIDAS requirements.
requirements.legalText:
Qualified trust service providers shall be subject to audits at least 
every 24 months by a conformity assessment body.

requirements.requirement: Notify supervisory body of changes affecting qualified status
requirements.explanation:
The QTSP must notify the competent supervisory body of any significant 
changes that could affect the qualified status, including organizational 
changes, security incidents, or policy modifications.

requirements.requirement: Use qualified electronic signature/seal creation devices (QSCDs)
requirements.explanation:
Qualified signatures and seals must be created using QSCDs that meet 
the requirements of Annex II of eIDAS, ensuring keys cannot be 
extracted and that the creation environment is secure.
requirements.legalText:
Qualified electronic signatures shall be created by a qualified 
electronic signature creation device.

requirements.requirement: Protect signature/seal creation data against duplication and theft
requirements.explanation:
The QTSP must implement comprehensive security measures to protect 
electronic signature creation data (private keys) from duplication, 
theft, or unauthorized access.
requirements.legalText:
Take appropriate measures against falsification and theft of data and 
against forgery or unauthorised modification of electronic signature 
creation data.

requirements.requirement: Maintain disaster recovery and business continuity capabilities
requirements.explanation:
The QTSP must have tested disaster recovery procedures and business 
continuity plans to ensure service availability and data integrity 
even in adverse circumstances.
requirements.legalText:
Have a termination plan to ensure continuity of service, and have a 
valid and up-to-date termination plan.

requirements.requirement: Notify supervisory body of security breaches within 24 hours
requirements.explanation:
The QTSP must notify the supervisory body without undue delay, and 
in any case within 24 hours, of any security breach with significant 
impact on the trust service or personal data.
requirements.legalText:
Where a trust service provider detects a breach of security or loss 
of integrity that has a significant impact on the trust service 
provided, it shall notify the supervisory body within 24 hours.

requirements.requirement: Implement secure remote signature creation (TS8) if offering remote QES
requirements.explanation:
If providing remote qualified signature services, implement the remote 
signature creation protocols specified in TS8, ensuring secure 
management of signature creation data on behalf of signatories.
requirements.notes:
Remote QES allows signatories to create qualified signatures using 
keys managed by the QTSP, rather than on a local QSCD.

requirements.requirement: Obtain sole control assurance for remote signing operations
requirements.explanation:
For remote qualified signatures, the QTSP must ensure the signatory 
has sole control over the signature creation process, typically 
through multi-factor authentication and explicit consent.
requirements.legalText:
An advanced electronic signature shall meet the following requirements: 
(d) it is linked to the data signed therewith in such a way that any 
subsequent change in the data is detectable.

requirements.requirement: Support WYSIWYS (What You See Is What You Sign) for document signing
requirements.explanation:
When creating signatures on documents, the platform must present 
the document content to the signer in a way that allows them to 
verify what they are signing before authorization.
requirements.legalText:
Where the payment service provider applies strong customer authentication, 
the authentication shall include elements which dynamically link the 
transaction to a specific amount and a specific payee.

requirements.requirement: Issue qualified timestamps from a trusted time source
requirements.explanation:
If providing timestamp services, qualified timestamps must be derived 
from an accurate and reliable time source traceable to Coordinated 
Universal Time (UTC).
requirements.legalText:
A qualified electronic time stamp shall meet the following requirements: 
(a) it binds the date and time to data in such a manner as to reasonably 
preclude the possibility of the data being changed undetectably.

requirements.requirement: Issue QEAAs only after verifying data from authentic sources
requirements.explanation:
Qualified Electronic Attestations of Attributes must be based on 
verified data from authentic sources. The QTSP must establish 
verified connections to authoritative data sources.
requirements.legalText:
A qualified electronic attestation of attributes shall meet the 
following requirements: (b) it is based on data from an authentic 
source or on data that has been provided and verified by the person 
to whom the attestation was issued.

requirements.requirement: Sign QEAAs with qualified electronic signature or seal
requirements.explanation:
Qualified attestations must be signed using the QTSP's qualified 
electronic signature or seal, providing legally recognized 
authenticity and integrity assurance.
requirements.legalText:
A qualified electronic attestation of attributes shall meet the 
following requirements: (c) it is issued by a qualified trust 
service provider and signed with a qualified electronic signature 
or qualified electronic seal.

requirements.requirement: Provide QEAA revocation capability through status lists
requirements.explanation:
QTSPs issuing QEAAs must maintain revocation infrastructure that 
enables relying parties to verify the current validity status 
of issued QEAAs.

requirements.requirement: Maintain sufficient financial resources or liability insurance
requirements.explanation:
QTSPs must maintain adequate financial resources or obtain appropriate 
liability insurance to cover damages arising from failure to meet 
their obligations.
requirements.legalText:
Qualified trust service providers shall use trustworthy systems and 
products that are protected against modification, and ensure the 
technical security and reliability of the processes supported by them.

requirements.requirement: Accept liability for qualified signatures/attestations issued
requirements.explanation:
The QTSP is liable for qualified services issued and must accept 
responsibility for failures in verification, revocation, or 
security of qualified certificates and attestations.
requirements.legalText:
Trust service providers shall be liable for damage caused 
intentionally or negligently to any natural or legal person due to 
a failure to comply with the obligations under this Regulation.

requirements.requirement: Comply with common Access Certificate Policy requirements
requirements.explanation:
Access Certificate Authorities must comply with the common Certificate 
Policy established by the Commission. This includes certificate issuance, 
validation, and revocation procedures for all ecosystem participants.

requirements.requirement: Handle suspension and cancellation of Trust Services
requirements.explanation:
When an Access Certificate Authority or Provider of registration certificates 
is suspended or cancelled, appropriate notification and transition procedures 
must be followed to maintain ecosystem trust.

requirements.requirement: Implement authentic source verification for QTSPs
requirements.explanation:
QTSPs accessing Authentic Sources for attribute verification must 
implement the specified technical interfaces, obtain User consent, 
and process verification responses according to ARF requirements.
